text: <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signals in B cells can also contribute to the activation of DNA recombination in the immunoglobulin heavy chain locus [ 11 ] , [ 12 ] .

This process , known as immunoglobulin class switching ( or isotype switching ) , allows B cells , initially expressing IgM , to switch to IgA , IgG , or IgE depending on the class of antibody most appropriate for a particular immune response .
Switching to IgE can be induced by the combination of <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signals .
The gene rearrangement necessary for IgE production is preceded by the production of non-coding RNA transcripts from germline sequences in the IgE heavy chain locus [ 13 ] .

To determine whether <extra_id_0> HOIP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is required in the initiation of the class switching process , the relevant B cell lines were stimulated through <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the presence of <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and tested for production of <extra_id_0> germline epsilon <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> GLepsilon <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) transcripts ( Fig . 3 ) .

Anti-CD40 antibody stimulation alone or together with <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induced <extra_id_0> GLepsilon <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcription in parental A20.2J cells as expected .
